posts.name: Tom Corrigan
posts.cooked:
Any reason an iPhone can’t be used on a robot in FRC? This cable, Redpark Ethernet Cable (L5~NET) ( redpark.com ) allows the iPhone to be plugged into an Ethernet port while disabling wifi on the phone at the same time. Putting the phone into airplane mode and turning off bluetooth would disable all other wireless communication. The only thing lacking at the moment is Network Tables client software.

A refurbished, unlocked iPhone 12 Pro can be gotten for less than $600.

Why would you want to do this? An iPhone has all the sensors you probably want in FRC in one package: high resolution camera, range finding lidar, accelerometer and gyroscope. Plus lots of computational power. It’s self-powered and easily mounted on a chassis.

Comments?

link_counts.title: Redpark Product Development - Connectivity Solutions for iPhone and iPad

posts.name: Sam Maier
posts.cooked: This was done with Android phones before the advent of the Limelight (for many of the same reasons you mention). See FRC-2016-Public/vision_app at master · Team254/FRC-2016-Public · GitHub as an example.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
tcorrigan5878:

Comments?

I bet if a student were to write a little phone app that did localization on an FRC field and sold it for $10, they’d be quite rich by high school standards.

Not my idea. Just an idea I like.

I mean since iPhones are basically more powerful than some cheap desktop processors (and are also abundant in American high schools) I don’t see why anyone wouldn’t do this. I think this is a good project for the next offseason with apriltags.

posts.name: Landonh12
posts.cooked:
‎AprilTags are 2D barcodes designed to be quickly and accurately detected, and are used in a variety of robotics and augmented reality applications. This application is an AprilTag detector that can be used in stand-alone mode, or can broadcast any...

This app detect apriltags and transmits data over UDP.

Also seems to lack the 3D pose estimation and camera calibration needed for that.

It actually wouldn’t be that hard to implement in iPhone since Apple is a big fan of using the same camera every year (mostly).
You have to take care to shock mount the phone. Constant vibrations have been known to destroy the OIS in iPhone sensors (motorcycles).
